facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 1061 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 30, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in W.P. No. 1061 of 1962.

facts.text: The appellant manufactures drugs in Hyderabad and among the drugs manufactured by it is chloral hydrate.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant manufactures drugs in Hyderabad and among the drugs manufactured by it is chloral hydrate.

facts.text: In September 1962, the State of Andhra Pradesh issued rules called the Andhra Pradesh Telangana Area Chloral Hydrate Chloral Rules, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In September 1962, the State of Andhra Pradesh issued rules called the Andhra Pradesh  Telangana Area  Chloral Hydrate  Chloral  Rules, 1962

facts.text: The Rules provide that the manufacture of chloral hydrate shall take place only in accordance with the conditions of a licence granted by the Excise Commissioner and only on payment of excise duty of Rs. 500/- per annum.

anchor.surface_text: with respect to manufacture, possession, sale, import, export and transport of chloral hyd- rate  hereinafter referred to as the Rules . We shall refer to the Rules in detail later but in brief they provide that the manufacture of chloral hydrate shall take place only in accordance with the companyditions of a licence granted by the Excise Commissioner and only on payment of excise duty of Rs. 5001- per annum.

facts.text: In consequence of the issue of the Rules, the appellant was called upon to take out a licence and pay the necessary excise duty.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of the issue of the Rules, the appellant was called upon to take out a licence and pay the necessary excise duty.

facts.text: The appellant refused to take out a licence and pay the excise duty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant refused to do so and in November 1962 filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging inter alia the validity of the Rules.

facts.text: In November 1962, the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging inter alia the validity of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant refused to do so and in November 1962 filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging inter alia the validity of the Rules.

facts.text: The Rules were issued under the Andhra Pradesh Telangana Area Intoxicating Drugs Act, No. IV of 1333 Fasli, as amended by the Hyderabad Opium and Intoxicating Drugs Amendment Act, No. XXII of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant contended that the 1333-F Act had been repealed in toto by the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act, No. 2 of 1930 by Act No. 33 of 1950 and Drugs Act No. 23 of 1940 by Part B States Laws Act No. III of 1951.

facts.text: The State case is that chloral hydrate increases intoxication if mixed with liquor and is produced in large quantities to be mixed with liquor.

facts.text: Parliament applied Dangerous Drugs Act No. 2 of 1930 to Part B State of Hyderabad by Central Act 33 of 1950.

issues.text: whether the Rules framed by the State of Andhra Pradesh in 1962 with respect to chloral hydrate were not within the powers conferred by the 1333-F Act as amended in 1953, as chloral hydrate was not a narcotic or narcotic drug and was not covered by item 51 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was contended that even if the 1333-F Act did not stand repealed as above, the Rules framed by the State of Andhra Pradesh in 1962 with respect to chloral hydrate were not within the powers conferred by the 1333-F Act as amended in 1953, as chloral hydrate was not a narcotic or narcotic drug and was not covered by item 51 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The 1333-F Act had been repealed in toto on the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act, No. 2 of 1930 by the Opium and Revenue Laws Extension of application Act, No. 33 of 1950, and of the Drugs Act, No. 23 of 1940 by the Part B States Laws Act, No. III of 1951, and therefore there was no power in the Hyderabad legislature to amend it by Act 22 of 1953. Consequently there was no law in force on the basis of which the Rules could be promulgated in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of -the appellant in the High Court was that the 1333-F Act had been repealed in toto on the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs. Act, No. 2 of 1930 by the Opium and Revenue Laws Extension of application Act, No. 33 of 1950, and of the Drugs Act, No. 23 of 1940 by the Part B States Laws Act, No. III of 1951, and therefore there was no power in the Hyderabad legislature to amend it by Act 22 of 1953. In consequence there was no law in force on the basis of which the Rules could be promulgated in 1962.

arguments.claim: There was no repeal of the 1333-F Act by the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act 1930 and the Drugs Act, 1940, and consequently the amendment of the 1333-F Act by the Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953 was good, and the 1333-F Act as amended was in force in 1962 when the Rules were framed.

arguments.claim: The 1333-F Act survived the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act because it deals with excise duties not covered by the central Act; s.39 preserves state laws with equal/greater restrictions; distinct fields.

anchor.surface_text: We come to the first point raised on behalf of the appellant, namely, whether the 1333-F Act survived the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act and the Drugs Act in the State of Hyderabad. The 1333-F Act was in force in Hyderabad State as it was before the Constitution from 1924.

arguments.claim: The 1333-F Act survived the Drugs Act 1940 as it is concerned with standards/quality, not excise duties; s.2 provides it is in addition to other laws.

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the Drugs Act of 1940 which was extended to the Part B State of Hyderabad by the Central Act III of 1951. Section 6 of the 1951-Act provides that if immediately before the appointed day, there is in force in any Part B State any law corresponding to any of the Acts or Ordinances not extended to that State, that law shall, save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, stand repealed.

arguments.claim: Chloral hydrate is a narcotic or narcotic drug within entry 51 List II; hypnotic/sedative; dictionary meaning; evidence of intoxicating effect with liquor; notified under 1333-F Act.
State affidavit words 'narcotic drug' refer to specific 1955 Act definition, not general meaning; chloral hydrate not covered by Dangerous Drugs Act but still narcotic.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant however relies on the statement in the affidavit filed on behalf of the State to show that chloral hydrate is not a narcotic or a narcotic drug within the meaning of entry 51 of List II, for if it is not a narcotic or a narcotic drug within that meaning no duty of excise can be imposed by the State legislature thereon.

arguments.claim: Chloral hydrate not a medicinal preparation under 1955 Act; point not properly raised before High Court.
Chloral hydrate is not a narcotic or narcotic drug within entry 51 List II per State affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The part of the affidavit on behalf of the State relied upon by the appellant was dealing with a vague allegation of the appellant that chloral hydrate was a medicinal preparation.

arguments.claim: Chloral hydrate is a medicinal preparation under Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act 1955.
Contentions of appellant repelled; writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition.

holdings.text: the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act in the Part B State of Hyderabad in 1950 did not result in complete effacement of the 1333-F Act. It remained alive even so far as opium, charas, bhang and ganja were concerned for the purpose of collection of duties of excise thereon. It also remained alive with respect to other substances which might be notified as intoxicating drugs under the 1333-F Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act in the Part B State of Hyderabad in 1950 did number result in companyplete effacement of the, 1333-F Act. It remained alive even so far as opium, charas, bhang and ganja were companycerned for the purpose of companylection of duties of excise thereon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dangerous Drugs Act concerns prohibition and control, not excise duties; s.39 preserves state excise laws with equal or greater restrictions; distinct fields under constitutional lists allow coexistence.

holdings.text: the Drugs Act of 1940 did not repeal the 1333-F Act insofar as it deals with collection of duties of excise; s.2 provides it operates in addition to other laws.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is numberforce in this argument either. The Drugs Act is mainly companycerned with standard and quality of drugs manufactured in this companyntry and therefore companytrols the manufacture, sale and distribution of drugs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drugs Act regulates standards and quality, not excise duties; s.2 explicitly states provisions in addition to, not derogation of, other laws; no implied repeal of state excise provisions.

holdings.text: There can be no doubt therefore that the 1333-F Act continued in existence so far as it dealt with collection of duties of excise on substances covered by it and it could therefore be amended by Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: There can be nodoubt therefore that the 1333-F Act companytinued in existence so far as it dealt with companylection of duties of excise on substances companyered by it and it companyld therefore be amended by Hyderabad Act No. 22 of 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1333-F Act as excise law survived central enactments; competent to amend for excise on notified intoxicating drugs.

holdings.text: chloral hydrate has been notified by the Government of Andhra Pradesh as an intoxicating drug within the meaning of the amended Act; Rules framed thereunder valid as within power conferred.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the second point raised in the present appeal, namely, that even if the 1333-F Act had number been companypletely repealed by the introduction of the Dangerous Drugs Act and the Drugs Act and companyld be properly amended by the Hyderabad Act of 1953, the Rules were number within the power companyferred by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended s.2(iv) allows notification of intoxicating/narcotic substances (excl. specified); chloral hydrate notified; excise control incidental to duty collection under List II entry 51.

holdings.text: There can be no other conclusion on the evidence in the present case than that chloral hydrate is a narcotic or a narcotic drug within the meaning of entry 51 of List II of the Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberother companyclusion on the evidence in the present case than that chloral hydrate is a narcotic or a narcotic drug within the meaning of entry 51 of List 11 of the Seventh Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypnotic/sedative properties per admission and dictionary; intoxicating when mixed with liquor; not limited to Dangerous Drugs Act definition; evidence supports.

holdings.text: not prepared to allow the appellant to raise [medicinal preparation under 1955 Act] for the first time before us.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also relies on the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act, No. 16 of 1955, in this Court. It is true that the appellant stated in its writ petition that it was holding a licence under the 1955-Act but there was numberclear averment in the petition that chloral hydrate was being manufactured as a medicinal preparation under the 1955-Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No clear averment in writ petition; not argued before High Court; licence under Drugs Act 1940; new point not entertainable in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petition challenging validity of the Chloral Hydrate Rules dismissed
